title: Strong Market Competition Framework
description: In 2024, Costa Rica achieved a Market Competition Overall Score of 68.55, reflecting a robust framework for promoting market competition.

title: Effective Implementation of Market Competition Services
description: Costa Rica scored 69.81 in 2024 for the implementation of key services promoting market competition, indicating effective policy execution.

title: High Government Investment in Education
description: In 2021, 31.17% of Costa Rica's government expenditure was allocated to education, showcasing a strong commitment to educational development.

title: Limited Coverage of Unemployment Benefits
description: As of 2022, only 19.02% of the population in Costa Rica was covered by unemployment benefits and active labor market programs, indicating limited social safety nets.

title: Disparities in Unemployment Benefit Coverage
description: Coverage of unemployment benefits in Costa Rica varies across income quintiles, with the 4th quintile having the highest coverage at 21.34% in 2022.

title: High Child Employment in Services Sector
description: In 2016, 53.5% of economically active children aged 7-14 in Costa Rica were employed in the services sector, highlighting child labor issues.

title: Gender Disparity in Child Employment
description: In 2016, 79.84% of economically active female children aged 7-14 were employed in services, compared to 45.5% of males, indicating gender disparity.

title: High Working Hours for Female Child Laborers
description: Female children aged 7-14 working only in Costa Rica averaged 44.16 hours per week in 2016, reflecting high child labor intensity.

title: Significant Proportion of Child Wage Workers
description: In 2016, 27.88% of children in employment in Costa Rica were wage workers, indicating a notable presence of child labor in formal employment.

title: High Child Employment in Agriculture
description: In 2016, 36.6% of economically active children aged 7-14 in Costa Rica were employed in agriculture, indicating a significant reliance on child labor in this sector.

title: Significant Female Child Labor in Agriculture
description: As of 2016, 20.16% of economically active female children aged 7-14 were employed in agriculture, highlighting gender-specific challenges in child labor.

title: High Unpaid Family Work Among Female Children
description: In 2016, 54.59% of female children aged 7-14 in employment were unpaid family workers, reflecting a high rate of unpaid labor among young girls.

title: Low Male Child Employment
description: Only 1.94% of male children aged 7-14 were economically active in 2016, suggesting a lower prevalence of child labor among boys compared to girls.

title: Negative Net Official Flows from UNWOMEN
description: In 2021, Costa Rica experienced a net outflow of $1,366 from UNWOMEN, indicating a negative financial interaction with this UN agency.
